Comment: I agree that border security should be fixed. I'm skeptical that a hiring spike for border patrol agents and a wall is the way to do that. I'm not sure what the actual solution is but it's probably a mix of a more thorough vetting and standards around hiring border patrol agents, and then a mix of monitoring technology and barriers. A wall would just have diminishing returns.

Hiring laws and self-deportation: I agree that we should enforce hiring laws. But we should find better legal ways for temporary workers. There is clearly a demand, let's find a way to have it on the books.

Trump is actually leaving no mat out for immigration. He's stated that he wants to deport, and also lower legal immigration. I disagree on both fronts.

You weren't willing to stand by deporting 11 million people, so you actually seem to be for some sort of pragmatic approach. Maybe the people on the other side of the fence want the same thing and aren't simply lawless criminals.

Comment: Read up a bit more on this, it will help. Here's a few pointers. 1st, as the article states, moose at this time of year are stressed out. It's not that they are dealing with overtime, bad roads, rude drivers, & office mismanagement. They are physically under duress, from lots of unwanted exercise (deep snow) & poor quality food (and less of it) so their bodies don't react well to being tranquilized. Moose sometimes die from it. 2nd, it's time-consuming to get to them with trained personnel. May take hours. Someone has to pay for that call as well. And pay for the chopper, fuel, pilot, etc. Weather may ground aircraft from being used. Ground vehicles may not be able to get in to the area. It's not simple or quick. Not even touching the paperwork side. Next, moose can't just be shot and eaten. AF&G has MANY rules on how a moose is 'disposed of' when shot, & most of the time the shooter can't keep it, especially an out-of-season kill.

Comment: It's not possible to determine "with certainty" (anybody that claims scientific certainty is selling you snake oil, at best you have strongly supported hypotheses), but there's a high probability it is, and virtually all evidence supports some degree of human influence.  

From a risk management perspective, you actually have to demonstrate rather the opposite - that a potential hazard is actually of negligible risk and thus so improbable that mitigation is unnecessary - and you have to satisfy the actuaries on this one.  

Thus, the burden of proof actually falls towards demonstrating it's not a threat (which is nearly impossible in practise)... since being skeptical means you have a huge question mark... and huge question marks are dangerous, since they mean there's a finite but real chance it will happen.. Again, think of the actuaries.

Comment: No one really hates dog-lovers  or pet dogs – but for the same reason that we have an  Anchorage ordinance against doing loud construction work after 9 PM,  neighbors need protection against  excessive  and  incessant noise from other sources – including dogs! 
For working people, late night and early morning dog barking interrupts a night sleep that's needed for the next working day. 
Newer types of shock collars have some pretty good features – Some have a warning "beep othat goes off when the dog barks the first time – if he barks at second time he gets a shock. Dogs quickly learn  that if they bark afterward  the beeper goes off – it will not be a fun moment.!
Also they have adjustable levels of shock for different size dogs. 
Social consideration and courtesy to neighbors does not have to be doomed to extinction! ( I wonder if there are shock collars for drivers of loud vehicles or players of insanely loud "music" – or whatever noise that stuff is!

Comment: 'Daily Maverick spoke to several hotels. It seems they are playing ball and doing their part for saving water.'

The other day De Lille said the influx of tourists this summer won't 'cripple the water supply if Capetonians save water'. She doesn't say how we're going to do more than we already are. So we must conserve water and give our share to visitors? Clueless and fatuous.
A study says the industry - tourists and supporting hospitality, transport, etc - use 2000-7500l per tourist per day. In 2016 the WC and city received 2.1m tourists, 1.6m foreign. In peak months Dec - March 150-160K foreign tourists a month arrived, or 500K total Dec 2016 (Wesgro/Cape Tourism). If each tourist uses 100l/day (it's probably more), total daily consumption = 50ML (500Kx100), excl supporting industry.

Comment: This article is flawed in a number of respects:

1. That good scholarship requires being open to challenge doesn't imply that any challenge is relevant to good scholarship. That is just bad logic and falsely implies that we (as academics and interested citizens) are not allowed to distinguish between cranks and legitimate criticism.

2. The piece is framed in relation to race, implying resistance to Rau may have been race-related. Is the author unaware that black mathematicians advised taking down Rau's piece for The Conversation?

3. Finally, author uses his ignorance about mathematics as a basis for endorsing Rau's invitation. It is not clear to me why the author's ignorance should be of concern to the rest of us.

The result is a poor attempt at pseudo-radicalism, that may indirectly discredit legitimate calls for decolonisation. See here for an earlier piece on this topic:
http://www.seanmuller.co.za/notesfromtheperiphery/2016/10/15/decolonising-mathematics-in-south-africa/

Comment: Like any social welfare program (and rent control is effectively a transfer of capital from property owners to renters), once it is in place "temporarily" it will become permanent, guaranteed.  If you want to argue otherwise, specifically when and under what circumstances do you see the rent freeze actually expiring?  Because if it won't expire in reality, and it's also bad long-term policy (it hasn't worked at all to keep housing generally affordable in NYC, SF, or LA), it shouldn't be implemented in the short-term either.

There are also plenty of good mom-and-pop landlords who risk having their lifetime investment (and often significant portion of their savings in the form of equity) ruined when they have no swift recourse to deal with a problem tenant and/or an unexpected large expense like a systems replacement.  Is an eviction worse than a foreclosure?  The current state of affairs is not good, but in my opinion the draconian measures PTU is proposing in response are worse.

Comment: You cherry-picked one election because the ADN published a recent piece about it. You're forgetting (or perhaps never knew about?) Instead of a new election, the courts devised some convoluted formula to tabulate disputed votes.

Long before there was such a thing as talk radio and KENI was a Top 40 station, their morning show satirized coverage of the Hammond / Hickel race. Comment: I think the problem we face as a Church is that we don't trust the Gospel. In my opinion, we should welcome -- indeed, seek out -- everyone to our communities and allow the power of the Gospel to lead us in spirit and truth. Instead of my confronting or degrading people who don't (appear to) measure up to my standards, I should be content to let the Gospel challenge us all to respond as it reaches into our hearts. 
In our big, anonymous, domesticated, coffee-and-donuts communities, we've replaced the Gospel with catechism answers and Pat-and-Mike stories, and none of us feels its power anymore: either the power to reform my life or the power to accept others as they do the same, without expecting them to keep pace with me or walk precisely the same road.
When push comes to shove, we're simultaneously the apostles at Easter AND the disciples who first left the comfort of their boats, taking a chance that what they heard would bring them what they needed.

Comment: "an impossible task"

One task that is far from impossible is the upholding of our very sensible federal regulations with regard to public safety.

Sections 33- 35 of the Onshore Pipeline Regulations (OPR) require that pipeline companies ensure that "anyone who is exposed to the risks" is informed of three things: the location of the nearby pipeline, what to watch out for (ie. indications of a failure) and how to respond if a failure should occur.

The need for such information is particularly acute at large, vulnerable facilities that are difficult to evacuate: high-rises, schools, transit hubs, hotels, geriatric facilities.  Ironically (and dangerously), there is an inverse relationship between vulnerability and awareness: the larger the facility, the less people know. This pattern has been confirmed and reported to the NEB during the past six years, yet no apparent action has been taken. 

People are at risk from a significant hazard that they are not aware of.

Comment: Your post saddens me. Not because I disagree, but because there is much truth in it.

My family came to Eugene two decades ago. We fell in love with the neighborhood grocery stores (Kiva, Red Barn, New Frontier, Sundance, Brun's Apple (formerly Red Apple)) and the incredible potential we saw here. That potential remains, but the direction over the past decade has been disturbing, at best. 

We're car-free, so we chose a location to live that put us close to all the amenities we want regularly without having to deal with horridly lousy streets. That puts us near the river. Twenty years ago, there were homeless people along the river, but they were few in both number and impact. In fact, they were kind of quaint and we helped several out, including providing housing. Now, the riverfront is disgusting, filled with garbage, feces, used needles and aggressive bums. Good night, what a difference.

I wish Mayor Vinis all the best, but I am now seriously considering relocating and it pains me.

We observe stellar nurseries, the deaths of stars, and billions of galaxies in all stages of their life. We see galaxies colliding, watch the rate at which they collide, and see what they look like long after they merge. Processes that take roughly 4 billion years to occur.

Comment: I used an American example because I know of no wealthy Canadian who has raised this matter.

Those who earn more income should pay a higher proportion in taxes than those who earn less.  A very basic example is the TFSA generally useful only to those with higher incomes where a $5,500 contribution by an individual has the same effect as raising their basic personal exemption by that amount thus shielding a modest amount of income from taxation. 

The real problem lies at the very top end of the income scale.  The very wealthy have means through aggressive tax strategies to reduce their taxable income by egregious amounts. Some also use extra-legal means to avoid taxation and go unpunished.  There is little difference between American and Canadian taxation avoidance in principle.

Comment: A reflection of their education, where the language and priorities of anti-racism, among other social-political concerns, permeates the curriculum of (mostly) the liberal arts and social sciences. This often results in creeping indoctrination because at the secondary school level any subtlety of analysis is almost impossible. Not hard to believe, since it seems to be almost impossible post-secondary as well. Many students leave high school having spent very little time in the courses where these questions are examined with any sophistication because it isn’t required within the 30 credit system. One required history course, one required social science course (of which economics is one of the choices). The BC Government has empowered Vancouver City (only around 20 to 25 percent of the GVRD) to do this but has done little to ensure that an appropriate taxation scheme can be created.

Assuming the Ontario proposal announced April 20th in this regard is as described now in the article, real progress might well be made to increase rental units available and discourage the holding of residential property vacant purely for speculation (and in a way that is neither contrary to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms nor to Canada's free trade agreement commitment.

Comment: "Desmond is a more viable option in the OF than CarGo." 

You keep saying this as if it's some cold, hard fact, and yet it's not supported by anything I see happening on the field. Much of Cargo's defensive value in RF is from his arm, which is still good enough to deter runners from going first-to-third on a single. Anyone who's seen Desmond make a throw from the OF is going to have no such reservations, as it's often hard to tell which base he's throwing to. And while Cargo's range isn't what it used to be, I don't think his lack of stolen bases indicates he "cannot run a lick" or that he can no longer play RF. Dwight Evans, Al Kaline and Roberto Clemente won 30 Gold Gloves between them and are arguably the three best defensive RFs of all time, and none of them were base stealers. 

I highly doubt Cargo will be back next year anyway, so Bud Black's not going to face this question. But I won't be surprised if Cargo plays RF for some team at least as long as Desmond does.

Comment: "Fairness has been difficult to achieve, because when it comes to forests the United States and Canada have fundamentally different economic systems. Timber in the United States comes from privately owned forests, or from public timber sold at auction in a competitive bidding process. Most Canadian timber is owned by the provinces, and is sold at prices set through an administrative process designed to ensure stable employment in the wood products industry."

Canada like many advanced democracies is fundamentally different than the U.S., not just with forests, but with all natural resources.  Canadian policy reflects the view that natural resources should be owned by the people and used to benefit the public. Comment: Let's try to explain it... Liquids expand when heated. A thermometer is UNDENIABLE PROOF that liquids expand when heated. The bulb at the bottom of a thermometer contains a liquid (usually red dyed alcohol). As the liquid is heated, it expands, and the level rises up the thin tube. DO YOU DENY THAT THERMOMETERS WORK? Water expands too. Put a glass measuring cup of water on a stove and heat it up. The water level will rise within the measuring cup. If you heat 500ml of water from 20 to 80 degrees C, the water level will rise about 6ml on the scale printed on the measuring cup. You can do this experiment and see with your own two eyes that water levels rise when heated. DO YOU DENY YOUR OWN TWO EYES? Okay, so global warming will only heat the oceans 1 or 2 degrees, but the average ocean depth is over 12,000 feet deep. A rise in water level of 1 foot in a 12,000 foot deep ocean is much smaller than a rise of 6ml in a 500ml cup, and only takes a couple degree change in ocean temperature.

Comment: I'm certainly no admirer of O.J. Simpson, but it needs to be said that parole was almost a certainty, given he was by all accounts a model prisoner, served the minimum sentence and most important of all, because under American jurisprudence, his past criminal charges and the subsequent controversial acquittal could not and should not have factored into the parole commissioners' decision.

Most anyone looking dispassionately at the 9-to-32 year sentence Simpson received for the botched robbery attempt comes away with a suspicion that this was simply extralegal payback for the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ron Goldman.  If you actually consider the light sentences (including just probation) that some of Simpson's compatriots received - some unlike Simpson, who were carrying guns - then on some level an uncomfortable sense that justice was not served is understandable.

People should never be above the law, but neither should anyone fall below what it stands for as well.

Comment: Part 1
Like I said Tridentinus, sounds to me like you haven't read the syllabus in a long time. Go back and give it a read, along with commentaries placing the list in historical context. Over and over again, the emerging ideas the syllabus condemned, have become truisms for virtually all modern people, including arch-conservative Catholics. 

As for Ratzinger, we have to distinguish the early (pre-1968) Josef from the later Josef. The early man was as progressive (in our terms) as they come; the later man was definitely interested in turning back the clock, but back to 1960 not 1860. Neither Ratzinger was an anti-Modernist as defined by the magisterium. 

As for scripture, I would suggest that Ratzinger's acceptance of modern scriptural scholarship as a method was complete, and this is perhaps a prime data point for establishing that he was not anti-Modernism.

Comment: Governments have little or no control over the economy and BC is no exception.

Anyone who has lived in BC for their entire lives will recognize the same economic pattern repeating itself, as it has done for 60 years that I can attest to.

BC's economy follows Canada's economy, but always 10 years in arrears.  As such, when Canada is doing well, BC's economy tends to do poorly, and when Canada is doing poorly, BC excels.  At this time, Canada's economy is starting to grow and BC's is starting to slow.

The mistake of voters on the right, is to assume that government has any control over the economy, which in a resource based economy, relies on world demand, and nothing more.  Harper learned this the hard way; by pretending that he controls the high growth, he also had to take the blame for poor growth.  Christy is no different.

Comment: The EU has an elected Parliament but one of they key complaints about the EU is that the Parliament has extremely limited power while the bureaucracy of the EU ends up making most of the rules.

As an obvious case in point, the EU Parliament has no authority to propose legislation.  All legislation has to originate from the European Commission which is an unelected body.  The EU Parliament can approve or decline that legislation, but can't really do much else.

Ohh, and the appointment of members of the European Commission?  That is handled by the Council of the European Union, which is ANOTHER unelected body, essentially like the Senate of the EU, being appointed by the executive of the member countries.

To say that the power of the EU Parliament is muted would be an understatement.

Comment: Actually, I think you may have this backwards.

The burden of proof is on the theist - the one making the claim for the existence of a god or gods.

I can claim that my neighbour's dog is the creator of the universe. It is not up to you to disprove that, it's up to me to prove it.

There is no - and I do mean no - rational, empirical, testable evidence for the existence of a divine super-entity, especially one that's interested in you as an individual.

And there are mountains of evidence that directly contradicts the existence of said super-entity.

That's not to say that evidence might not arise tomorrow, but as it is now, and in thousands of years of trying, the evidence just isn't there.

All that said, by all means, if your faith provides you comfort and a sense of community, then have at it. Just keep it out of the schools, courtrooms and legislative assemblies and don't ask for a tax break.

Comment: We never welcomed immigrants because we were good or had high ideals.

At first America needed people to settle the continent so we had open immigration.  
We then passed laws to limit or exclude Chinese and Japanese.  Later quotas were added to reduce/prevent the immigration of Irish, Italians and Polish.  You know, Catholics.  Additional modifications were added which resulted in reduced immigration from Mexico and Latin America.  See http://connection.ebscohost.com/us/immigration-restrictions/history-immigration-laws-us

There was never an idea of open immigration in America.  Immigration was always used or directed for a specific purpose.  To fill up the space.  To get laborers.  To get skilled workers.

Comment: Rick, Thanks for the correction on the income tax rates.  I'll have to stop saying that to  my Alberta friends and relatives, and stick to the sales tax.
But as far as the resource revenue, that is neither here nor there.  The 50% factor means that effectively half of the resource revenue is deducted from the equalization amount.    One could argue that 100% should be deducted not just 50%.  But aside from that, Albertans conveniently forget their resource revenue when they whine (and boy do they whine) about equalization payments.  The other thing many of them don't realize is that the government of Alberta doesn't pay one cent to the other provinces under the formula.  It's a distribution based on federal taxes collected from all citizens.  In that sense we all pay into the kitty regardless of province.  And Alberta gets nothing back because of their resource revenue.
I don't buy the Quebec/N.B. argument either.  Alberta can leave theirs in the ground too.  It's their choice.

Comment: I agree with much of your comment, except for the guitar Mass, which I find to be an abomination, but that's my taste. I also find the "Four Hymn" framework tiresome.  The Roman Missal, if followed properly, has an entrance antiphon, communion antiphon, sung Gloria, Psalm, Eucharistic Antiphons...quite a bit of sung prayer in the Mass, if it were simply celebrated properly.  And, the idea that every spare second of the Mass just has to be filled up with music is ridiculous - sacred silence is nearly nonexistent in our liturgies now, yet God speaks, most often, in the silence, and in our day and age, silence is something most people never experience, yet at the same time, desperately need.

Comment: I think sometimes, we miss what's laying right in front of us, as we look to find "something bigger." For all the media hype/spin (OMG, did Trump say THAT????, or compare president X versus president Y's response, etc...), the REAL story was not partisan politics, it was not racism, it was not sexual politics, religion or anything else.

The real story in the Houston floods was that "rednecks" from Louisiana created a VERY long caravan of people pulling flat-bottomed boats, heading IN to Houston, to help rescue people. The real story in Las Vegas was the number of everyday people who put their own lives on the line and dove back INTO the concert venue to try to help get others out, even as a crazed madman was still shooting.  Etc...

The real story here is consistent: when the chips are down, people rise above racism, sexism, economic disparity and religion. Everyday people set ALL of that aside to help each other. To me, THAT's what to watch for in all of this, not the talking heads.

Comment: When I was young, my father taught new Canadians who had come here from European refugee camps after the war. Most Sunday afternoons for many years we had visitors to our home who had been my father's students. Among them were several men and women who had been imprisoned in Nazi concentration camps. Some were Jews and several that I remember were 'gypsies'. Needless to say, they were all quite happy and grateful that they were now Canadians.

After a time, they all found jobs and many started their own businesses. The visits became less frequent and eventually stopped as they settled into Canadian life. 

Canada was at one time deserving of its reputation as a haven for refugees. Is there any reason that our country of 35 million people, one of the wealthiest countries in the world, can no longer accommodate such as small number of immigrants and refugees? Have we become that fearful and selfish?

Comment: "The thesis for anthropogenic climate change is that prior to fossil fuel burning, the terran climate was static. "
BZZZT! Wrong.

The Earth's climate changes for many reasons, and the clue in there is the word "reason". When it changes, it changes for a reason.
Currently, solar activity is low, which is cooling the earth, but CO2 has rapidly climbed to its highest level in millions of years, which offsets the current "cool" solar stage we're in by a factor of about 50:1, so that's why the Earth is warming.

Comment: The effects of our cumulative GHG emissions into the atmosphere, primarily carbon dioxide, are increasingly evident. In 1979 at the September low point there were 17,000 cubic kilometers of sea ice in the Arctic. In 2017 we are on track for roughly 3,000 cubic kilometers of sea ice in the Arctic. This is an 82% loss of Arctic sea ice in a very, very short period of time. No one knows exactly when the Arctic will be entirely ice free in September but 2025 is as good as a guess as any (the error limits on the 2025 number are small).

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: W H Auden wrote a poem at the start 0f WWII, "September 1, 1939" (the day the Germans invaded Poland). The last two stanzas (which Auden later dropped from the poem) are

All I have is a voice 
To undo the folded lie,
The romantic lie in the brain
Of the sensual man-in-the-street
And the lie of Authority
Whose buildings grope the sky:
There is no such thing as the State
And no one exists alone;
Hunger allows no choice
To the citizen or the police;
We must love one another or die.

Defenceless under the night
Our world in stupor lies;
Yet, dotted everywhere,
Ironic points of light
Flash out wherever the Just
Exchange their messages:
May I, composed like them
Of Eros and of dust,
Beleaguered by the same

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery. Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Most "poor" (ie at or near poverty level) qualified for expanded Medicaid.  GOP wants to slash that both the money available for expanded Medicaid and roll back the poverty threshold to 100% instead of 133%.  The people that didn't fall below that threshold, but up to about 400% of the federal poverty level (about $50k for an individual) we given a cap on the total premiums with a subsidy provided to cover the balance.  GOP wants to replace these subsidies with "refundable tax credits" based more on age that income.

Mostly the "poor" and low-middle income were financially improved by ACA.  The ones that were "hurt" were those who's (cheap near useless) policies were cancelled for not having compliant coverage.

ACA didn't help the rich any any way, and imposed new taxes.  GOP wants to get rid of those.

So "repeal and replace" hurts the lower income that were helped for the most part by ACA, and helps the wealthy with less taxes.

Comment: Profits go up when women are in the boardroom? 
It’s a compelling argument, but there’s no actual evidence that it’s true. Lots of studies show a correlation between higher female board representation and higher returns, but no one has definitively proven causation; that it’s the act of adding women that drove the financial performance. Profitability is far too complex to be solved that simply. There may be well-grounded reasons for increasing women’s presence on boards, but enhanced financial performance isn’t one of them, and a 2010 study of companies in Norway, where a law requires 40% of board seats to be filled by women, showed that financial performance declined.

Comment: Regarding when to take CPP and OAS:  I did not see much consideration for tax brackets in the discussion.  If you have a sizable RRSP which when converted to a RRIF will force minimum payments at a higher taxable rate, would it be advantageous to delay CPP/OAS until 70 and live solely on RRSP withdrawals from 65 to 70.  That way there will be less going into the RIFF and the minimum withdrawals will be lower.  Is this a beneficial strategy or will the higher CPP/OAS at 70 counteract the reduced minimum?
Say you have $900K in RRSPs + 100K in non-registered at age 65 when you retire.  How would you minimize the income tax paid over the next 25 years (keeping below the 45k bracket)?
65 - 70: RRSP withdrawal only at 55K/year plus 20K from non-registered
70 - 71: CPP/OAS 25K + 35 K RRSP plus 15K from non-registered
This would leave 700K (assuming low growth ) for RRIF conversion
71 - 99: CPP/OAS plus RRIF minimum

Comment: Under the first-past-the-post system, views like those of Leitch were actually represented in the Harper government which, because of our system, held nearly absolute power with few parliamentary checks. Many of the positions put forth by the Conservatives during the last election were actually quite close to those of Leitch. The problem is that, under the current system, a party with quite dangerous views could still, with just 38% of the votes, have 100% of the power. In contrast, proportional representation - while it might enable some with fringe views to enter parliament - would ensure that the voices of moderation could easily overwhelm such views and ensure that only policies (the result of compromise among parties) with quite widespread support became law.

Comment: Canada has no credibility internationally on ghg emissions.  We were the second worst performer of the Kyoto signatories having committed to a 6% decrease but by 2012, our emissions were up by 21%.  A 27% "miss".  Only Saudi Arabia was worse.

The two main drivers of our emissions increase were; #1 mass immigration, contributing about 65% by adding 6 million people and #2, the increased production from the oil sands at around 35%.

Despite the noise about a carbon tax, which is a positive measure, there is no coherent strategy to lower emissions and governments have increased even further the rate of immigration and allowed for higher oil sands production.

Canada as a leader in the climate change fight is strictly an image campaign waged in and by the media.

Cheers,
John Meyer

Comment: I checked. There was general agreement in the scientific community that the hiatus did actually occur. However, suddenly in 2015 Thomas Karl then director of the NOAA came up with a set of data that "proved" that the hiatus actually never occurred. This was just before the Paris climate conference. I do not have the time to attempt to get to the real truth, but it seems that they managed to prove that the temperature increase did not slow down, by recalculating the temperature increase that occurred before the "slowdown". In other words, the average temperature increase during the "hiatus" remained what it was, but the average temperature increase for the preceding 50 years was recalculated down, i.e. when the data did not suit their model, they "recalculated" the data, not the other way round. Sounds fishy?

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: See previous post. This is the 2nd of two proposed poll questions for the next Civil Beat poll on rail: 

2) According to the City’s Environmental Impact Statement, traffic congestion will be worse in the future than it is today, even if rail transit is built. Knowing that traffic congestion will be worse in the future than it is today, even with rail transit, which statement most closely represents your opinion:  

The final EIS, which spells out the details of the rail project, is thousands of pages long. Consequently, the public has had to rely on other sources of information to learn about rail - news stories, politicians, pro and anti-rail marketing campaigns and community outreach education by HART. That is why it is crucial that public polls on rail include basic, undisputed facts in the questions they pose to respondents.

Comment: It is so sad and tragic that people continue to smoke in this day and age, when so much more is now known about the effects.

When I was a young boy back in the early 1960's, my Dad would take me to visit my step-grandfather, who had been a heavy smoker.   He developed emphysema, and he was wasting away.   The poor man was in a wheelchair, and had to be constantly hooked up to an oxygen tank in order to still survive.   He labored so hard to breathe.   You could hear his gasps and all the wheezing that came from his chest, as he struggled so badly to get oxygen into his body.

He died such a slow and agonizing death.   Seeing him suffer so horribly from smoking really had quite an impact on me as a young boy.  I was absolutely terrified by the sight of his suffering.

Comment: I tend to agree as well, however the flip side is that the DIY approach also entails risk and that applies even for stocks that look stable and conservative today. A truly diversified portfolio will help mitigate some of that risk but it's not the same as having the risk outsourced through an annuity. Dividend stocks can go to zero, an annuity won't (assuming it stays within the limits of the Assuris guarantee). Annuities are for people who fear they will outlive their money and don't have much in the way of pensions, they are financial products as opposed to income investments.

Comment: The NPVIC is simply replacing one electoral sleight of hand with another. Our present system gives less populous states a somewhat louder voice. Comment: Yes indeed - and our system is very much built on the premise that is is "better to let 10 guilty men go free than to let 1 innocent man be jailed". Other criminal systems do not take that approach - such as in China where the conviction rate is something like 98% and trials are basically a foregone conclusion heavily stacked in the prosecution's favour - the philosophy there is to maximize convictions at the expense of locking up many innocent people in the process. It is very much a legal expression of a more collectivist culture and political philosophy. 

In Canada, individualism and individual rights against government power come first, so the system heavily favours the accused, both with the presumption of innocence, and the fact that the entire burden of proof rests on the Crown (i.e. the accused doesn't have to prove his innocence in court because he is already considered innocent and it is entirely on the Crown to bring the case for guilt).

Comment: Your previous post (sorry if I misread) that you can only have sex when you *intend* pregnancy is not accurate regarding Church teaching.  You don't have to intend it, just allow it. The question of having sex in a way that "avoids pregnancy", which seems a new one in this thread, is definitely more complicated.  While the Church generally teaches that natural family planning is not sinful, it can be used in a way that the Church teaches is wrong.  

 The point is that we are not supposed to use people for gratification, even ourselves, even with consent. Love people, use things, not the other way around.

Comment: As someone who has been involved with the regulations on sulphur emissions from ships since 2004 I have to say the author has rather missed the boat (insert bad pun groan here).

Exhaust gas cleaning systems can be installed on ships to eliminate the sulphur and dramatically reduce the particulate matter allowing the ships to use cost effective heavy fuel oil (HFO) 

The alternative is to refine the HFO into diesel fuel. This. however, creates additional CO2 emissions, has a significant cost impact, and does little to reduce the most harmful sub 5 micron particulate emissions. 

The technology is relatively new and is installed on only small part of the commercial fleet. As it matures, additional PM, NOx and CO2 reductions will be possible. 

As for the 1000's of cars emissions comparison - this is a misleading statement at best.  How many pickup trucks would it take to deliver grain from Thunder Bay to the global markets? Several thousand. I have a much better idea, use a ship.

Comment: OF COURSE bringing Pandas to Toronto was a waste of money.  Sure, blame the Aquarium, bad weather, a strike, or bad karma...IMHO I blame zoo management, the Toronto Zoo Board and City Council:

1. For decades the Zoo was subsidized by the City.  For the last ten years (or more), the City provided the Zoo with $12 Million each year.  Most zoos today are non-profits, funded by a non-governmental group (ie. "Friends of ___ zoo").  At the same time, admission and parking continue to climb.
2. Membership pricing is completely out-of-whack.  A family pass pays for itself in less than two visits (subsidized by City taxes), while residents of Pickering, Ajax, Whitby and other cities close-by takes advantage.  Many tourists don't bother making the trek to east Scarborough.  Regular admission is $25...twenty-five BUCKS.
3. The current "state of good repair" to bring the zoo to a reasonable level of infrastructure quality requires in the neighbourhood of $100 Million...and it increases each year.

Comment: Jim,
Please get the facts straight when you quote information.  The study of school wells can be found here   https://public.health.oregon.gov/HealthyEnvironments/DrinkingWater/SourceWater/Pages/pdp-schools.aspx
There were 22 schools in the State of Oregon that had their wells tested.  The purpose of this sampling project was to collect data on the national prevalence of pesticides and pesticide breakdown products in school well water. Participation in this project was voluntary and analytical results were provided to participating schools. The data collected in this project will be used for national research and risk assessments of these chemicals to specifically address the drinking water component for children during their developmental years. The data will be published by the USDA. The summary described and reported on the collective test results in Oregon.  CONCLUSION   None of the pesticides or their breakdown products were found at levels of concern for public health.

Comment: You are right, but missing the broader point. In a nutshell:

If there was something called "freedom of speech" entrenched in the US constitution, it was because the VALUE of free speech was deemed essential to a democracy, and that concept spread to other western democracies, thanks to "the Left" which led the battle against censorship of movies, books, art, etc., unions which fought for the right of employees not to be fired for their political opinions, etc. 

It wasn't long ago that Free Speech was a basic value of the Left, and they argued for it with all the familiar arguments, "the answer to speech you disagree with is more speech, not censorship", etc.

Those are the same arguments used by "the Press" in favor of ITS "freedom of the press".

If one believes in those argument against censorship by governments, why would one not believe in them against censorship BY the press, of comments by its readers? That is self-contradictory.

Comment: There was no "explosion in Toronto's real estate  that happened a week after BC's Foreign Buyer Tax".

The Toronto real estate market has been hot for several years - and continuously since March 2009.  The fundamental demand drivers are net inbound migration of 100,000 people a year (which creates demand for 70,000 new housing units every year).  Millennials coming of age and wanting to buy real estate (who often don't own a car), and a lack of new supply in the City (where the number of new single-family units built in a year is less than 1,500, almost all of which are replacements for smaller houses, not net additional homes)

The Wynne government's "intervention" seems to have led to a pause by buyers, but it can't and won't last because the fundamentals of the market have not changed.  And the extension of rent control to new buildings will inevitably bring a halt to new rental unit construction, which will inevitably make the problem worse (after the 2018 election, of course)

Comment: The mature view is that the US, on the one hand, and Mexico and Canada, on the other, benefit from NAFTA and would benefit further from updates reflecting the needs of economies that have evolved over the past 3 decades. Likewise, all would suffer a brutal transition and loss of many long term benefits if NAFTA was terminated.

These will be tough negotiations and may be punctuated by one side or the other suspending negotiations or threatening to terminate NAFTA.  However, there are good reasons to believe that after prolonged negotiations a viable compromise solution will emerge.

The key is for Canada and Mexico to remain steadfast and reasonable and not allow themselves to become overawed or bullied into accepting unreasonable concessions to the US or into foregoing reasonable US concessions as part of the final bargain.
